title: 111_s2819
content: The Act may be cited as the "Processed Food Safety Act of 2009". It includes provisions for poultry safety. The Poultry Products Inspection Act is amended to include requirements for accurate labeling of poultry products, specifying the name, description of cuts, and distributor information. The Poultry Products Inspection Act is amended to include labeling requirements for poultry products, prohibiting certain acts related to selling or transporting poultry for human consumption. The Poultry Products Inspection Act now requires certification that ingredients in poultry products have undergone pathogen reduction treatment or testing to reduce harmful contaminants. The Poultry Products Inspection Act mandates pathogen reduction treatment for ingredients in poultry products, with a phase-in period of 18 months after enactment for certain provisions. SEC. 3. MEAT SAFETY. The Federal Meat Inspection Act is amended to include requirements for accurate labeling of meat products, including the name, description of each cut of meat, and distributor information. The Federal Meat Inspection Act is amended to include requirements for accurate labeling of meat products, with changes to specify the use of spices, flavorings, and colorings in labeling. Prohibited acts are outlined in Section 10, including requirements for pathogen reduction treatments for meat or meat food products sold in commerce. The Federal Meat Inspection Act is amended to include requirements for accurate labeling of meat products, with changes to specify the use of spices, flavorings, and colorings in labeling. Prohibited acts are outlined in Section 10, including requirements for pathogen reduction treatments for meat or meat food products sold in commerce. A phase-in period of 18 months after enactment is established for compliance with new regulations regarding testing and certification of ingredients to ensure they contain no verifiable traces of pathogens. SEC. 418 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act introduces pathogen reduction treatment requirements for meat products to enhance food safety. The Secretary will require facilities registered under section 415 to apply pathogen reduction treatments to food manufactured, processed, packaged, or held for consumption in the United States. Facilities must certify to the Secretary that food contains no verifiable traces of pathogens or has received required pathogen reduction treatments. The requirements of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act will not apply until 18 months after the enactment of the Act. A technical amendment is made to Section 402 regarding facility certification. Labeling rules for spices, flavorings, and coloring under Section 403 are also amended. The amendment allows products to be designated as spices, flavorings, and colorings without specifying each one individually. It also exempts butter, cheese, and ice cream from certain artificial coloring provisions. Additionally, it replaces specific subsection references with a more general term.
